questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is experiencing persistent headaches and frontal sinus pain. A radiograph is taken with the patient in a chin-down position to assess the involvement of the frontal sinus. What is this imaging view called?
questions.explanation:
View

Position

Purpose

Image

Waters' View (Occipitomental View)

(Option A)

Chin-up position.

Best view to visualize the maxillary sinus.

Pierre’s View

(Option B)

Similar to Waters' view but with the mouth open.

Best view to visualize the sphenoid sinus.

Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View)

(Option C)

Chin-down position.

Best view to visualize the frontal sinus.

Lateral View

(Option D)

Lateral (as the name indicates)
  • Allows visualization of all sinuses (frontal, maxillary, sphenoid, and ethmoidal).
  • Helps to understand the pneumatization pattern of the sphenoid sinus.

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the white arrow in the CT scan of the nose and paranasal sinuses shown below
questions.explanation:
CT Scan of Nose and Paranasal Sinuses

Initial Cuts (Anterior to Posterior)

Anterior Cut:

  • Structures visible: Nasal cavity, nasal bone structures, cartilaginous septum, and frontal sinus

Progressing cuts:

  • Nasal bones and bony portion of septum
  • Frontal sinus

Middle Region Cuts
  • Maxillary sinus
  • Inferior turbinate and septum
  • Middle turbinate
  • Concha Bullosa (Option D ruled out): Air-filled or pneumatized middle turbinate, which can cause headaches, due to obstruction or irritation of surrounding structures.
  • Ethmoidal air cells
    • Agger Nasi: (Option C ruled out): The anterior-most ethmoidal air cell, visible before the middle turbinate.
    • Bulla Ethmoidalis (EB) (Option A ruled out): The largest ethmoidal air cell, visible further posteriorly.
    • Haller cell: Located inferomedially to the orbit, often extending below the middle turbinate, can contribute to obstruction or sinus issues.

Posterior Cuts

Sphenoid sinus

Concha Bullosa

Agger Nasi

Bulla Ethmoidalis (EB)

Haller Cell

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with suspected mastoiditis. The ENT surgeon orders a Law’s view X-ray to assess the mastoid. Which of the following best describes this view?

options.label: A
options.text: Lateral oblique view with a 15º tilt

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral oblique view with a 30º tilt

questions.correct_answer: A. Lateral oblique view with a 15º tilt
questions.explanation:
X-ray Projection

Beam Angle & Positioning

Structures Seen

Clinical Applications

Law's View (15° lateral oblique)

Sagittal plane of the skull parallel to the film; 15° cephalocaudal beam angle (Option A).
  • Mastoid air cells
  • External Acoustic Meatus (EAC)
  • Tympanic cavity
  • Evaluation of mastoid air cells
  • Mastoiditis
  • Mastoid pneumatization

Schuller's View (30° lateral oblique)

Similar to Law's view, but the beam is angled 30° cephalocaudal(Option B)
  • EAC superimposed on IAC
  • Mastoid air cells
  • Lateral sinus plate
  • Condyle of mandible
  • Attic-antral region
  • Mastoiditis
  • Destruction of intercellular septa
  • Cholesteatoma
  • Longitudinal petrous fracture

Stenvers View (Axio-anterior oblique posterior)

Head slightly flexed and rotated 45° opposite to the side under examination; beam angled 12° cephalad
  • Posterior cranial fossa
  • Semicircular canals
  • IAC
  • Vestibular system
  • Acoustic neuroma
  • Petrositis
  • Cholesteatoma

Towne's View (30° fronto-occipital axial)

Anteroposterior view with 30° tilt from above and in front. (Option C)
  • Both temporal bones
  • Arcuate eminence
  • Superior semicircular canal
  • Mastoid antrum
  • EAC
  • Tympanic cavity
  • Cochlea
  • Acoustic neuroma
  • Apical petrositis

Transorbital View (AP/PA)

Orbito-meatal line perpendicular to the film; X-ray beam perpendicular to the film from the submental area

EAC, Mastoid air cells, Mastoid process, Cochlea, IAC, Vestibule, Base of skull, Orbital rim

General assessment of mastoid and adjacent structures

Submentovertical View (full axial)

Head and neck hyperextended, orbito-meatal line parallel to the film; beam at right angles to the film

Skull base structures, Mastoid process, Petrous apex, Tympanic cavity

Skull base fractures, mastoid involvement, temporal bone fracture

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding sialography is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Sialography helps diagnose salivary duct issues.

options.label: B
options.text: Contrast dye is injected into the salivary duct.

options.label: C
options.text: Restricted dye flow indicates potential salivary stones.

options.label: D
options.text: Dye is injected into the salivary gland’s blood vessels.

questions.correct_answer: D. Dye is injected into the salivary gland’s blood vessels.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:D) Dye is injected into the salivary gland’s blood vessels.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with severe dysphagia, stridor, and a stiff neck. The physician orders a lateral soft tissue X-ray of the neck as shown. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition on the lateral soft tissue X-ray of the neck?

options.label: A
options.text: Widening of the Prevertebral Soft Tissue Shadow

options.label: B
options.text: Air Bubbles in the Soft Tissues

questions.correct_answer: D. Narrowing at the subglottic region.
questions.explanation:
Acute Retropharyngeal Abscess

Chronic Retropharyngeal Abscess (Prevertebral Abscess)

Causes
  • Children: Lymphadenitis of lymph nodes of Rouvier
  • Adults: Penetrating injury
  • TB spine (Caries spine)

Clinical features
  • Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing
  • Stridor and croupy cough
  • Torticollis
  • Bulge in posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Discomfort in throat
  • Dysphagia is not marked
  • Posterior pharyngeal wall shows a fluctuant swelling centrally or on one side of midline
  • Neck may show tuberculous lymph nodes

O/E:

Bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall

Unilateral deviation

Diffuse midline

X-ray findings
  • Widening of Prevertebral Soft Tissue Shadow: (Option A)
    • Soft tissue shadow is twice the size of the vertebral body.
  • Straightening of Cervical Spine: (Option C)
    • Loss of normal curvature.
  • Presence of Air Bubbles: (Option B)
    • Indicates possible infection or abscess formation.

X-rays are diagnostic in case of caries of cervical spine

Treatment

IV antibiotics → incision & drainage

Antitubercular treatment

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a slowly enlarging, painless neck mass near the angle of the mandible. An angiogram of the neck shows the image below:  What is this sign known as?
questions.explanation:
Carotid Body Tumor (CBT)

Definition & Origin
  • A type of paraganglioma
  • CBTs are benign, slow-growing vascular tumors derived from neural crest cells.

Location

They arise from the carotid body, a small chemoreceptor located at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery.

Epidemiology
  • CBTs are the most common paraganglioma of the head and neck.
  • Familial CBT is associated with mutations in the SDH gene (Succinate Dehydrogenase Complex Gene - SDHB, SDHD).

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless, slow-growing neck mass
  • Symptoms due to compression of nearby structures, such as dysphagia, hoarseness, or a bruit on auscultation.
  • Catecholamine-secreting tumors can cause systemic symptoms like hypertension, palpitations, and sweating.

Imaging
  • CT Angiogram/ DSA: Lyre sign (Option A) - splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries.
  • MRI: Salt and pepper appearance

Management

Surgical resection

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the clinic with painful neck stiffness and torticollis four days after undergoing adenoidectomy for chronic adenoiditis. Physical examination reveals restricted neck movement in all directions and a “cock-robin” position of the head. Neurological examination is normal. Which of the following best describes the underlying condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation following cervical injury

options.label: B
options.text: Non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation secondary to infection or surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Atlanto-occipital dislocation caused by a congenital cervical spine anomaly

options.label: D
options.text: Acute cervical disc herniation causing torticollis

questions.correct_answer: B. Non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation secondary to infection or surgery
questions.explanation:
Grisel's Syndrome

Etiology

Nontraumatic atlantoaxial subluxation (Option B), often secondary to upper respiratory infections or post-surgery in the head and neck region (e.g., adenoidectomy).

Pathophysiology

Loosening of the transverse and alar ligaments due to inflammation in the atlantoaxial joint.

Presentation
  • Painful torticollis
  • neck stiffness
  • "Cock-robin" head position.

Imaging

X-ray or CT shows rotational subluxation of C1-C2.

Management
  • Early intervention with bed rest
  • Cervical immobilization
  • Antibiotics
  • Anti-inflammatory agents to prevent neurological sequelae.

Complications of adenoidectomy
  • Hemorrhage (most common)
    • Primary hemorrhage: Occurs intraoperatively from the surgical site.
    • Reactionary hemorrhage (within 24 hours of the surgery): occurs due to the displaced clot or slippage of ligature.
    • Secondary hemorrhage(24 hours upto 14 days of surgery): Occurs due to infection.
  • Injury to pharyngeal musculature and cervical vertebrae.
  • Injury to Eustachian tube opening.
  • Grisel's syndrome
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency
  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis
  • Recurrence

questions.text: A 40-year-old male has a deviated septum with a significant dislocation at the caudal end. The surgeon prefers a unilateral approach, avoiding a full-thickness incision. Which incision is most appropriate in this case?
questions.explanation:
Types of septal incisions for septoplasty

Killian’s (Option A)
  • In the nasal mucosa, cephalic to the caudal end of the septum
  • Slightly curvilinear incision, 2-3 mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side.

Transfixion (Option C)
  • Through and through incision, close to but caudal to caudal end of the septum.
  • Used in caudal septal dislocation

Hemitransfixion

(Freer’s incision)

(Option B)
  • Same as the transfixion incision but on one side, not through and through.
  • Used in caudal septal dislocation
  • Septocolumellar incision between caudal end of septal cartilage and columella.

Horizontal on the Spur (Option D)
  • For endoscopic spurectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe nasal obstruction, headaches, and a history of multiple nasal surgeries for chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. On endoscopic examination, there is extensive polyposis with distortion of normal anatomical landmarks. The surgeon decides to use a posterior-to-anterior surgical approach for better access and disease clearance. Which surgical technique is most appropriate in this case?
Which of the following statements, regarding the different types of mastoidectomy, is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Canal Wall Down mastoidectomy preserves the integrity of the postero-superior canal wall

options.label: B
options.text: Schwartze’s mastoidectomy is a type of Canal Wall Down mastoidectomy

options.label: C
options.text: Modified radical mastoidectomy involves the removal of the postero-superior canal wall

options.label: D
options.text: In Canal Wall Up mastoidectomy, the mastoid cavity remains open.

questions.correct_answer: C. Modified radical mastoidectomy involves the removal of the postero-superior canal wall
questions.explanation:
CANAL WALL UP (CWU)

CANAL WALL DOWN (CWD)

Simple/ cortical/Schwartze's Mastoidectomy (Option B)

Modified Radical Mastoidectomy/ Bondy's Procedure (Option C)

Classic Intact Canal Wall, Combined

Approach Tympanoplasty (CAT)

Radical Mastoidectomy
 

Atticotomy
 

Atticoantrotomy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of chronic otitis media. Examination shows a dry tympanic membrane perforation without active infection. She has a 30 dB hearing loss. Which of the following procedures is most appropriate to improve her hearing?

options.label: B
options.text: Myringoplasty using a temporalis fascia graft

questions.correct_answer: B. Myringoplasty using a temporalis fascia graft
questions.explanation:
Procedure

Purpose

Additional Information

Myringoplasty

Close perforation, improve hearing

Underlay/overlay graft placement

Myringotomy

Relieve pressure from fluid buildup

Often combined with grommet insertion

Grommet insertion

Drain fluid (Otitis media with effusion)

Synonymous with tympanostomy tube

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a chronic middle ear infection presents with a perforated tympanic membrane and erosion of the malleus. Based on Wullstein's classification of tympanoplasty, which type of tympanoplasty would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Type I (Myringoplasty)

Repair of a perforated tympanic membrane with a graft. (Option A ruled out)

Type II

Graft placed on the incus or malleus remnant due to malleus erosion. (Option B)

Type III

Graft placed on the stapes head when malleus and incus are absent. (Option C ruled out)

Type IV

Graft placed between the oval and round windows when only the stapes footplate remains; cavum minor created. (Option D ruled out)

Type V

Fenestration in the horizontal semicircular canal, creating a new window with a graft. Performed when stapes footplate is fixed.

questions.text: Identify the instrument used to reduce fractures of nasal septum.
Which of the following is not a characteristic of the Saint-Clair Thompson Adenoidectomy Curette?

options.label: A
options.text: It is held like a dagger in the dominant hand

options.label: B
options.text: It is used with limited direct visualization, often blind

options.label: C
options.text: It is used without the cage for larger pieces of adenoid tissue

options.label: D
options.text: The curette is inserted under the soft palate to remove tissue using an inferior to superior motion.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used without the cage for larger pieces of adenoid tissue
